contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "all over the world" or 2) "to the places on earth that are farthest away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: to the ends of the earth

contextId.information: "the Lord Jesus lived among us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: the Lord Jesus went in and out among us

contextId.information: Here the words "poured out" mean that Jesus who is God made these events to happen. It is implicit that he does this by giving the Holy Spirit to the believers. AT: "he has caused these things to happen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Possible meanings are 1) "they shared their meals and ate together in their homes" or 2) "they celebrated the Lord's Supper together in their homes." See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:act:02:40|2:42]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Possible meanings are 1) "looking directly at him" (UDB) or 2) "looking intently at him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the phrase "before the face of" means "in the presence of." AT: "rejected in Pilate's presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: rejected before the face of Pilate

contextId.information: Here the word "sons" refers to heirs who will receive what the prophets and the covenant promised. AT: "You are the heirs of the prophets and heirs of the covenant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
contextId.quote: You are the sons of the prophets and of the covenant

contextId.information: Here the words "look upon" are a request for God to take notice of the way in which the Jewish leaders threatened the believers. AT: "notice how they threaten to punish us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This means that they presented to money to the apostles. AT: "presented it to the apostles" or "gave it to the apostles." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:04:34|4:35]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: laid it at the apostles' feet

contextId.information: Here the word "heart" refers to the will and emotions. Possible meanings are 1) "Satan completely controlled you" (UDB) or 2) "Satan convinced you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the phrase "rose up" means that the high priest decided to take action, not that he stood up from a seated position. AT: "the high priest took action" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This means that they seized the apostles by force. They would have ordered guards to do this. AT: "had the guards arrest the apostles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This means that he persuaded some people to rebel with him against the Roman government. AT: "caused many people to follow him" or "caused many people to join him in rebellion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: drew away some people after him

contextId.information: The phrase "handed down" means "passed on." AT: "taught our ancestors" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Possible meanings for this phrase are 1) enough ground to stand on or 2) enough ground to take a step. AT: "a very tiny piece of ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: enough to set a foot on

contextId.information: "he thought about and decided." This is an idiom that means "he decided" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This does not mean their necks were stiff but rather that they were "stubborn." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"extremely angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The idiom "was with him" means "was helping him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"completely" or "fully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"under the care of"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means Herod had the believers arrested. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:05:17|5:18]]. AT: "sent soldiers to arrest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"God chose David to be their king." Here "raised up" is an idiom that means God caused David to become the king.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: he raised up David to be their king

contextId.information: This expression means he "is a man who wants what I want." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: to be a man after my heart

contextId.information: This phrase is another way of saying Paul and Silas where causing trouble everywhere they went. The Jewish leaders were exaggerating the influence Paul and Silas were having with their teaching. AT: "caused trouble everywhere in the world" (UDB) or "caused trouble everywhere they have gone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole|Hyperbole]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "laid hands on" means to "seize" or to "grab." See how you translated "laid hands on" in [[:en:bible:notes:act:05:17|5:18]]. AT: "grabbed Paul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This was a customary way of saying no harm would come upon them. AT: "every one of you will survive this disaster unharmed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: not one hair of your head will be lost
